item.title: Addition
item.description: Caption: Adding numbers

item.title: Algorithm
item.description: a list set of instructions, used to solve problems or perform tasks, based on the understanding of available alternatives, like making a recipe.

item.title: Alphabet
item.description: The word “alphabet” is said as “ABC” in ASL but fingerspelling is a foundation of ASL, and is often used when a certain sign is not known.

item.title: Binary
item.description: binary is a system where numbers and values are expressed 0 or 1. Binary is base-2, meaning that it only uses two digits or bits. For computers, 1 is true or “on”, and 0 is false or “off”

item.title: Bug
item.description: In computer science, a “bug” is simply a term for a coding error, the process of discovering bugs is refered to as “debugging”

item.title: Child
item.description: An element that is nested within another element.

item.title: Class
item.description: a template definition of the methods and variables in a particular kind of object.*

item.title: Code
item.description: the composition of sequences of instructions, called programs, that computers can follow to perform tasks.

item.title: Coding
item.description: the composition of sequences of instructions, called programs, that computers can follow to perform tasks.

item.title: Computer Science
item.description: The study of computation, information, and automation.

item.title: Decimal
item.description: relating to or denoting a system of numbers and arithmetic based on the number ten, tenth parts, and powers of ten

item.title: Decode
item.description: To convert an encoded message into an itelligible language

item.title: Divide
item.description: a mathematical operation which involves the sharing of an amount into equal-sized groups

item.title: Download
item.description: copy (data) from one computer system to another, typically over the internet.

item.title: Encrypt
item.description: convert (information or data) into a cipher or code, especially to prevent unauthorized access.

item.title: Equals
item.description: be the same as in number or amount

item.title: For Loop
item.description: runs a section of code repeatedly until a certain condition has been satisfied. For-loops have two parts: a header and a body.

item.title: Function
item.description: a unit of code that is often defined by its role within a greater code structure.

item.title: Integer
item.description: a number that is not a fraction; a whole number.

item.title: Internet
item.description: a global computer network providing a variety of information and communication facilities, consisting of interconnected networks using standardized communication protocols.

item.title: Laptop
item.description: a computer that is portable and suitable for use while traveling.

item.title: Loop
item.description: a sequence of instructions that is continually repeated until a certain condition is reached.

item.title: Math
item.description: area of knowledge that includes the topics of numbers, formulas and related structures, shapes and the spaces in which they are contained, and quantities and their changes.

item.title: Method
item.description: a procedure associated with a class. A method defines the behavior of the objects that are created from the class.

item.title: Multiply
item.description: A mathematical operation that indicates how many times a number is added to itself.

item.title: Node
item.description: Nodes are a basic data structure which contain data and one or more links to other nodes. Nodes can be used to represent a tree structure or a linked list.

item.title: Number
item.description: an arithmetical value, expressed by a word, symbol, or figure, representing a particular quantity and used in counting and making calculations and for showing order in a series or for identification.

item.title: Object
item.description: an object is an abstract data type with the addition of polymorphism and inheritance. Rather than structure programs as code and data, an object-oriented system integrates the two using the concept of an “object”.

item.title: Operating System
item.description: the software that supports a computer’s basic functions, such as scheduling tasks, executing applications, and controlling peripherals.

item.title: Or
item.description: A boolean expression that is given two inputs, the output is “true” if either or both of the inputs are “true.” If both inputs are “false,” then the output is “false."

item.title: Parent
item.description: *A node that is above and attached to another node *

item.title: Pi
item.description: The number π is a mathematical constant that is the ratio of a circle’s circumference to its diameter

item.title: Repository
item.description: A repository, or repo, is computer storage for maintaining data or software packages. This location contains files, databases, or information organized for quick access over a network or directly.

item.title: Return
item.description: *A return statement ends the execution of a function, and returns control to the calling function. *

item.title: Rubber Ducky
item.description: THE FOUNDATION OF COMPUTER SCIENCE, WITNESS ITS POWER!

item.title: Server
item.description: a computer or system that provides resources, data, services, or programs to other computers, known as clients, over a network.

item.title: Subtract
item.description: take away (a number or amount) from another to calculate the difference.

item.title: Type
item.description: an attribute associated with a piece of data that tells a computer system how to interpret its value.

item.title: Unequal
item.description: to not be the same as in number or amount.

item.title: Upload
item.description: *the transmission of data from a local device to a remote device. Typically, the remote device is a larger server. *

item.title: Virus
item.description: Definition here
